newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo naphtha lower, Aramco spot offers seen.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo naphtha lower, Aramco spot offers seen.

text.p: Tokyo naphtha prices fell in afternoon trade on Wednesday, in the wake of weaker crude oil futures which shed more than 60 cents per barrel in New York and London, traders said.

Benchmark open-spec naphtha for second-half August delivery was assessed at $206.50/208.00 per tonne. It was quoted at $210.00/211.50 in late Tuesday dealing. In spreads, first-half July/second-half July was traded at minus $2.00.
Saudi Arabia's Aramco was rumoured to be offering spot parcels of A-180 and Jubail cargoes for lifting in June to September, traders said.
Aramco is offering a total of about 400,000 tonnes of naphtha, traders said. The offer price was unavailable.
Activity in the physical naphtha market remained lacklustre on the back of high domestic inventories.
"Stocks are really high. We can do without buying spot cargoes probably until the end of August," one trader with a petrochemical firm said.
In the low sulphur waxy residue (LSWR), a South Korean oil company said it plans to buy about 400,000 barrels of Indonesian cargoes for June-lifting.
